Description: Black granite plinth for monument of Ramses II and Queen Meritamun: this rectangular block is incised on one side with the Horus name, prenomen and nomen of Ramses II and the name of Queen Meritamun. Along the other three sides are two inscriptions giving the titles of Meritamun. The shallow depression at the top of the monument indicates that it was probably the plinth of a statue. This piece is extremely well preserved apart from some wear to the bottom. There are no traces of colour.
Curator's comments: Princess Meritamun is named in the inscriptions of Ramses II as his fourth daughter, and it is known from Abu Simbel that she was the eldest daughter of Queen Nefertari (H. Gauthier, 'Le Livre des Rois d'Égypte' III (Cairo, 1914), 104-5; C. Desroches-Noblecourt and C. Kuentz, 'Le petit temple d'Abou Simbel' (Cairo, 1968), 22-5). She was raised to the rank of queen probably after the death of her mother, although it is not certain whether the marriage to her father was nominal or not. (W. Helck, ‘Chronique d’Égypte’ 44 (1969),22-4). For her monuments see Gauthier, 'Le Livre des Rois d'Égypte' III, 104-5, and L. Habachi in Berlin Museum, 'Festschrift zum 150jährigen Bestehen des Berliner Ägyptischen Museums' (Berlin, 1974), 103-12. She was buried in Tomb 68 in the Valley of the Queens (B. Porter & R. Moss, 'Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts, Reliefs and Paintings' I (2) (Oxford: Clarendon Press), ii, 765-6). Bibliography. The British Museum, 'British Museum Quarterly' 4 (1929-30). 3; K.A. Kitchen, 'Ramesside Inscriptions' 2 (Oxford, 1979), 925, no. 392(A).
Bibliographic references: Bierbrier 1982 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum, Part 10. (pl.17)
Condition: Good. This piece is extremely well preserved apart from some wear to the bottom.
